subject: Gardening
title: Plant Hunters' Dangerous Missions
description: A 1-minute de-risking session on Plant Hunters' Dangerous Missions.

hook.text: Victorian plant hunters risked death to bring back a single flower. Many never returned home.

buildup.text: Empires sent botanists to remote jungles, mountains, and deserts searching for exotic specimens.

discovery.text: David Douglas, who gave us the Douglas fir, fell into a bull trap in Hawaii and was gored to death.

twist.text: Many 'discoveries' were plants indigenous peoples had cultivated for centuries. Credit rarely went to them.

climax.text: Plant hunting shaped global agriculture. Rubber, tea, and quinine all came from these expeditions.

punchline.text: Your garden exists because someone risked everything.

quiz.question: What often-overlooked fact complicates the legacy of plant hunters?
options: Most plants they 'discovered' were already cultivated by indigenous peoples
They only collected ornamental flowers, not useful crops
